text: now the squat can be considered by all
intents and purposes the king of all
exercises we're going to focus on the
quadriceps the glutes but it also
involves a tremendous amount of the
upper body and hamstrings as well in
order to support and develop the
musculature so the first thing is when
you walk up to the bar Chris wants to
set his hands just beyond shoulder width
now what will happen with a lot of
people when they're doing the squat is
to put their arms a little bit wider
very common with more of a powerlifter
stance the problem is if you have an
issue with tilting forward when you do
the squat it's going to throw you
forward a little bit so one of the
things you can do is move your hands in
just a little bit now what Chris is
going to do is you're going to stand up
with the bar and he's going to walk it
back from the rack just a little bit now
the position he has is a little bit of
what we call a high squat in terms of
where the bar is he could also move it
down slightly and put it more right in
the groove between the traps and the
rear delts in order to get a little bit
more leverage especially as you go
heavier part of its dependent on
personal preference what we're going to
have Chris do is he's going to take a
slightly wider than shoulder width
stance don't make your stance too narrow
because you're going to make it a lot
harder to balance when you do this now
the important part with the squat is
it's just like trying to sit back down
in a chair what we want to make sure is
that the hips knees and ankles all hinge
at the same time the other thing you
want to keep in mind when you're doing
the squat is you want to keep your core
tight so before you ever start to go
down into the squat position contract
your midsection now what's important in
this is you notice he keeps his lower
back nice and flat notice he's actually
got a slight curve in it one thing we
don't want to do is have him arch when
he does this go ahead and do it the
wrong way Chris so we want to prevent
the back from curving like this and what
we're going to do instead is we want to
try to tuck that low back in so that his
butt sticks out a little bit the bottom
then what you're going to see is his
hips his knees and his ankles
all extend at the same time as one unit
so that's proper technique on a squat
remember to let your hips and knees move
simultaneously try to keep your low back
slightly curved it's a lordotic tilt and
keep your head up not dropping and not
looking straight up at the ceiling move
your hands in a little bit if you tend
to tilt forward and keep your elbows
pointing at the floor and you're already
on your way to proper squat technique
